clusters.title: Nearly 1,500 flights canceled on second day of cuts tied to government shutdown
clusters.neutral_headline: US Airlines Cancel Flights Due to Government Shutdown

items.title: Nearly 1,500 flights canceled on second day of cuts tied to government shutdown
items.standfirst: Charlotte, North Carolina, has the most cancellations – at 120 – as industry experts say other sectors might also feel effectsUS airlines canceled 1,460 flights on Saturday, the second day of the Federal Aviation Administration’s (FAA) order to reduce air traffic because of the government shutdown.So far, the slowdown at many of the nation’s busiest airports hasn’t caused widespread disruptions. But it has deepened the impact felt by what is now the nation’s longest federal shutdown. Continue reading...
items.content: Charlotte, North Carolina, has the most cancellations – at 120 – as industry experts say other sectors might also feel effectsUS airlines canceled 1,460 flights on Saturday, the second day of the Federal Aviation Administration’s (FAA) order to reduce air traffic because of the government shutdown.So far, the slowdown at many of the nation’s busiest airports hasn’t caused widespread disruptions. But it has deepened the impact felt by what is now the nation’s longest federal shutdown. Continue reading...

items.title: Flight cancelations to worsen next week if shutdown continues

Trump administration officials this week ordered airlines to start cutting flights at 40 busy U.S. airports on Friday, blaming…

items.title: USA: Hundreds of flights canceled nationwide amid government shutdown cuts
items.standfirst: More than 5,000 US flights were delayed or canceled on Friday, the first day of new mandates requiring airlines to cut air traffic as the government shutdown continues. The rules, implemented at 40 of the nation’s busiest airports, aim to reduce pressure on air traffic controllers and other federal workers who are reporting to duty without pay amid the historic funding impasse. Professor of Computer Science at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champain, Sheldon H. Jacobson, gives his insights.
items.content: More than 5,000 US flights were delayed or canceled on Friday, the first day of new mandates requiring airlines to cut air traffic as the government shutdown continues. The rules, implemented at 40 of the nation’s busiest airports, aim to reduce pressure on air traffic controllers and other federal workers who are reporting to duty without pay amid the historic funding impasse. Professor of Computer Science at University of Illinois at Urbana-Champain, Sheldon H. Jacobson, gives his insights.

The FAA ordered airlines to reduce flights due to air traffic controller shortages.
Charlotte, North Carolina, had the most cancellations, with 120 flights affected.
The government shutdown has deepened the impact on the nation's airports.
A ground delay program was issued at Nashville International Airport due to staffing.

items.content: In Tampa, Florida, four people were killed and more than a dozen were hurt after a car crashed into a crowded bar.

items.title: Car fleeing police slams into bar in Tampa, killing 4 people and injuring 11
items.standfirst: Police say vehicle was involved in street racing before driver fled from authorities and then crashed into Ybor City bar A speeding car fleeing police slammed into a crowded bar early on Saturday, killing four people and injuring 11 in a historic district of Tampa, Florida, known for its nightlife and tourists.An air patrol unit with the Tampa police department spotted the car driving recklessly on a freeway at about 12.40am after police said the silver sedan had been seen street racing in another neighborhood, according to a police department statement. Continue reading...

items.content: A deadly crash in Tampa's Ybor City neighborhood early Saturday morning has left four people dead and 11 injured.

items.title: At least four killed by Russian strikes in Ukraine
items.standfirst: A Russian drone slammed into a tower block in eastern Ukraine early Saturday while many were sleeping, killing four and injuring 12 people, Ukrainian authorities reported. Shirli Sitbon has the latest.
items.content: A Russian drone slammed into a tower block in eastern Ukraine early Saturday while many were sleeping, killing four and injuring 12 people, Ukrainian authorities reported. Shirli Sitbon has the latest.

items.title: Massive Russian attack damages Ukraine's energy network, killing one
items.standfirst: A large-scale Russian attack damaged Ukraine's energy infrastructure prompting emergency power outages, Ukrainian authorities said on Saturday, as the emergency services said a Russian drone strike on a nine-storey building in Dnipro killed one woman and wounded six people. France24 correspondent Emmanuelle Chaze reports the latest from Kharkiv.
items.content: A large-scale Russian attack damaged Ukraine's energy infrastructure prompting emergency power outages, Ukrainian authorities said on Saturday, as the emergency services said a Russian drone strike on a nine-storey building in Dnipro killed one woman and wounded six people. clusters.title: Tanzanian police arrest senior opposition official, hundreds charged with treason

items.title: Tanzanian police arrest senior opposition official, hundreds charged with treason
items.standfirst: Tanzanian police on Saturday arrested a senior official from the opposition Chadema party and charged hundreds of people with treason in a continuing crackdown following last month's disputed elections.
items.content: Tanzanian police on Saturday arrested a senior official from the opposition Chadema party and charged hundreds of people with treason in a continuing crackdown following last month's disputed elections.

items.title: Tanzania arrests senior opposition figure as hundreds face treason charges
items.standfirst: Opposition party Chadema said that its deputy secretary-general, Amani Golugwa, was arrested early on Saturday.
items.content: Opposition party Chadema said that its deputy secretary-general, Amani Golugwa, was arrested early on Saturday.

items.title: Tanzania police arrest opposition party official after deadly election protests
items.standfirst: Chadema party says deputy secretary general arrested and calls election of incumbent president fraudulentTanzanian authorities have detained a senior official from the main opposition party, Chadema, amid a spate of arrests in connection to deadly protests during elections last week.More than 1,000 people were killed by security forces during the demonstrations, according to Chadema and human rights bodies. The Tanzanian government has said these figures were exaggerated but did not give its own figures. Continue reading...
items.content: Chadema party says deputy secretary general arrested and calls election of incumbent president fraudulentTanzanian authorities have detained a senior official from the main opposition party, Chadema, amid a spate of arrests in connection to deadly protests during elections last week.More than 1,000 people were killed by security forces during the demonstrations, according to Chadema and human rights bodies. The Tanzanian government has said these figures were exaggerated but did not give its own figures. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Supreme Court allows Trump admin. to temporarily pause full SNAP payments
clusters.neutral_headline: Supreme Court Halts Full SNAP Payments Temporarily

items.title: Supreme Court allows Trump admin. to temporarily pause full SNAP payments
items.standfirst: Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson on Friday froze, for now, a lower court order that required the Trump administration to swiftly provide full SNAP benefits to roughly 42 million Americans.
items.content: Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson on Friday froze, for now, a lower court order that required the Trump administration to swiftly provide full SNAP benefits to roughly 42 million Americans.

items.title: Millions who depend on SNAP in limbo as Supreme Court blocks full payment for now
items.standfirst: Millions of Americans who depend on federally funded food assistance programs, known as SNAP, remain in limbo as the Supreme Court temporarily blocked a full payment of SNAP benefits for now. Willie James Inman has the latest.
items.content: Millions of Americans who depend on federally funded food assistance programs, known as SNAP, remain in limbo as the Supreme Court temporarily blocked a full payment of SNAP benefits for now. Willie James Inman has the latest.

items.title: Supreme Court rules full Snap food benefits can be temporarily halted
items.standfirst: The US Supreme Court has issued an emergency order temporarily permitting the Trump administration to withhold billions of dollars in funding for food assistance relied on by millions of low-income Americans. The decision follows a White House appeal after a lower court had ordered that payments from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps, be fully distributed to recipients by Friday. France24 International Affairs Editor Kethevane Gorjestani gives her insights.
items.content: The US Supreme Court has issued an emergency order temporarily permitting the Trump administration to withhold billions of dollars in funding for food assistance relied on by millions of low-income Americans. The decision follows a White House appeal after a lower court had ordered that payments from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps, be fully distributed to recipients by Friday. France24 International Affairs Editor Kethevane Gorjestani gives her insights.

ai_summary: The Supreme Court temporarily blocked full SNAP benefit payments.
The lower court order required full SNAP benefits for 42 million.
Millions who depend on SNAP remain in limbo due to the ruling.
The Trump administration can temporarily withhold SNAP funding.
The decision followed a White House appeal to the court.

items.title: US consumer sentiment drops to near record low as shutdown persists
items.standfirst: Economic concerns felt by Americans of different ages, incomes and political affiliations, survey findsThe federal government shutdown dragged consumer sentiment in the US to a near record low in November, according to a monthly survey conducted by the University of Michigan.Consumer sentiment fell about 6% in November, with the consumer sentiment index for November 2025 at 50.3, down from 53.6 in October, nearly three points below expectations. Economists polled by the Wall Street Journal expected a 53.0 index reading. Continue reading...
items.content: Economic concerns felt by Americans of different ages, incomes and political affiliations, survey findsThe federal government shutdown dragged consumer sentiment in the US to a near record low in November, according to a monthly survey conducted by the University of Michigan.Consumer sentiment fell about 6% in November, with the consumer sentiment index for November 2025 at 50.3, down from 53.6 in October, nearly three points below expectations. Economists polled by the Wall Street Journal expected a 53.0 index reading. Continue reading...

ai_summary: US consumer sentiment dropped to near the lowest on record.
The government shutdown weighed on the economic outlook.
High prices soured views about personal finances.
The preliminary November sentiment index dropped to 50.3.
The index is just above a June 2022 reading of 50.

clusters.title: Ireland's FA passes vote seeking UEFA ban on Israel competing in European competitions
clusters.neutral_headline: Ireland's FA passes vote seeking UEFA ban on Israel competing in European competitions

items.title: Ireland's FA passes vote seeking UEFA ban on Israel competing in European competitions
items.standfirst: The governing body for football in the Republic of Ireland has approved a resolution to call on UEFA to suspend Israel and its club sides from European competitions.
items.content: The governing body for football in the Republic of Ireland has approved a resolution to call on UEFA to suspend Israel and its club sides from European competitions.

items.title: Irish football chiefs pass vote seeking Uefa ban on Israel from European competition
items.standfirst: Republic of Ireland body alleges two statute violations FAI approved a resolution to submit a formal motionThe Football Association of Ireland (FAI) has approved a resolution to submit a formal motion to Uefa urging it to ban Israel from European club and international competitions.The governing body’s resolution – proposed by the Dublin club Bohemians – cited alleged violations by the Israel Football Association (IFA) of two provisions of Uefa statutes. They are its alleged failure to implement and enforce an effective anti-racism policy and the organisation of clubs in occupied Palestinian territories without the consent of the Palestinian FA. Continue reading...
items.content: Republic of Ireland body alleges two statute violations FAI approved a resolution to submit a formal motionThe Football Association of Ireland (FAI) has approved a resolution to submit a formal motion to Uefa urging it to ban Israel from European club and international competitions.The governing body’s resolution – proposed by the Dublin club Bohemians – cited alleged violations by the Israel Football Association (IFA) of two provisions of Uefa statutes. They are its alleged failure to implement and enforce an effective anti-racism policy and the organisation of clubs in occupied Palestinian territories without the consent of the Palestinian FA. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) approved a resolution.
The resolution will submit a formal motion to UEFA.
The motion urges UEFA to ban Israel from competitions.
The resolution cites alleged violations of UEFA statutes.
Alleged violations include failure to enforce anti-racism policy.

clusters.title: France urges citizens to leave Mali temporarily due to jihadist blockade
clusters.neutral_headline: France urges citizens to leave Mali temporarily due to jihadist blockade

items.title: France urges citizens to leave Mali temporarily due to jihadist blockade
items.standfirst: France has urged its citizens in Mali to leave immediately, as Islamist insurgents maintain their blockade of the country. The French Foreign Ministry recommended that citizens use commercial flights while they are still available and avoid traveling overland. The two-month-long fuel blockade, enforced by an al-Qaeda-linked group, has disrupted daily life in the capital, Bamako, and other parts of the landlocked West African nation, a former French colony. A. Fenaux and S. Sitbon have this story.
items.content: France has urged its citizens in Mali to leave immediately, as Islamist insurgents maintain their blockade of the country. The French Foreign Ministry recommended that citizens use commercial flights while they are still available and avoid traveling overland. The two-month-long fuel blockade, enforced by an al-Qaeda-linked group, has disrupted daily life in the capital, Bamako, and other parts of the landlocked West African nation, a former French colony. A. Fenaux and S. Sitbon have this story.

items.title: France urges citizens to leave Mali as armed group blockade intensifies
items.standfirst: France has urged its citizens to leave Mali “as soon as possible” as an al-Qaeda-linked group, the Group for the Support of Islam and Muslims (JNIM), has been blockading fuel tankers since September, disrupting the flow of imported goods from Senegal and the Ivory Coast and upending daily life in Bamako and other regions of the West African country. Assistant professor of Anthropology at Lehigh University and Mali specialist, Bruce Whitehouse, joins us for more insights.
items.content: France has urged its citizens to leave Mali “as soon as possible” as an al-Qaeda-linked group, the Group for the Support of Islam and Muslims (JNIM), has been blockading fuel tankers since September, disrupting the flow of imported goods from Senegal and the Ivory Coast and upending daily life in Bamako and other regions of the West African country. Assistant professor of Anthropology at Lehigh University and Mali specialist, Bruce Whitehouse, joins us for more insights.

items.title: France advises citizens to leave Mali urgently amid jihadist fuel blockade
items.standfirst: The blockade, imposed by jihadists, has upended daily life in the landlocked nation.
items.content: The blockade, imposed by jihadists, has upended daily life in the landlocked nation.

ai_summary: France urged its citizens in Mali to leave immediately.
Islamist insurgents maintain a blockade of the country.
The blockade has disrupted daily life in Bamako.
The blockade has been in place for two months.
The blockade is enforced by an al-Qaeda-linked group.

clusters.title: At least 54 people injured in explosions at Indonesian school mosque
clusters.neutral_headline: More than 50 people injured in blast at mosque in Jakarta school complex

items.title: At least 54 people injured in explosions at Indonesian school mosque
items.standfirst: Authorities say suspect is 17-year-old male student and warn against terrorist attack speculation after Jakarta blasts At least 54 people have been injured in explosions that shook a mosque at a high school during Friday prayers in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta. Authorities later said the suspect was a 17-year-old male student who had been injured and was undergoing surgery.Witnesses told local television stations that they heard at least two loud blasts at about midday, just as the sermon had started, from inside and outside the mosque at SMA 72, a state high school within a navy compound in Jakarta’s northern Kelapa Gading neighbourhood. Continue reading...
items.content: Authorities say suspect is 17-year-old male student and warn against terrorist attack speculation after Jakarta blasts At least 54 people have been injured in explosions that shook a mosque at a high school during Friday prayers in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta. Authorities later said the suspect was a 17-year-old male student who had been injured and was undergoing surgery.Witnesses told local television stations that they heard at least two loud blasts at about midday, just as the sermon had started, from inside and outside the mosque at SMA 72, a state high school within a navy compound in Jakarta’s northern Kelapa Gading neighbourhood. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Authorities say a 17-year-old suspected of causing the explosion during Friday prayers is in surgery.
items.content: Authorities say a 17-year-old suspected of causing the explosion during Friday prayers is in surgery.

ai_summary: Explosions occurred at a mosque in Jakarta.
The mosque is located in a school complex.
Authorities say a 17-year-old is the suspect.
The suspect is a male student.
